DOCNAME: CASE OF DE MOOR v. BELGIUM
CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection rejected (non-exhaustion);Violation of Art. 6-1;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award - domestic proceedings;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . ORG The applicant , a NORP national born in DATE , pursued a career in the NORP army . In DATE he retired with the rank of capitaine - commandant . On DATE he gained a law degree .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE Mr ORG informed the Chairman of ORG that he intended to apply for enrolment on the list of pupil advocates . On DATE he had an interview with the Chairman .

CARDINAL . ORG , when it learnt of the applicant ’s intention at its session on DATE , reacted in a somewhat unfavourable manner , but took the view that it was unnecessary to give a decision as no formal application had been made .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , in the course of a telephone conversation , the Chairman of ORG allegedly told the applicant that ORG had decided not to enrol him because he had completed CARDINAL full career and FAC already had CARDINAL members .
CARDINAL . ORG By a letter of CARDINAL DATE Mr ORG submitted an application in the prescribed form .
CARDINAL . ORG At a meeting on DATE ORG decided to consult the Chairman ( doyen ) of ORG .

On DATE , after considering the latter ’s opinion , according to which there were no grounds for refusing Mr ORG application ( " er geen argumenten zijn om ORG FAC te weigeren " ) , the ORG appointed CARDINAL rapporteurs from among its members .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the Chairman read out the report of the first rapporteur , which was unfavourable , and the second submitted a comprehensive report on the matter . During the deliberations , it was pointed out that Mr ORG had not taken the oath and had therefore not been entitled to seek enrolment . DATE the ORG rejected the application .

CARDINAL . ORG The Chairman of ORG informed Mr ORG of this decision in a letter of CARDINAL DATE . He stated that it was consistent with the practice followed by ORG according to which persons who had completed a full career outside the Bar were not admitted to the list of pupil advocates .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE Mr ORG filed an application in the PERSON d’Etat to have the decision set aside on the ground that ORG did not constitute an " independent and impartial tribunal " within the meaning of Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) of the Convention .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG produced its statement of defence . It argued that the PERSON d’Etat lacked jurisdiction and that Mr ORG had no interest in the proceedings inasmuch as he had not taken the oath and could not therefore be enrolled on the list of pupil advocates . On the merits , it affirmed that a refusal to enrol could be based on reasons other than those justifying disciplinary measures . The fact that the applicant had already completed CARDINAL full career justified the impugned decision , particularly because he had stated that , as his income was sufficient , he wished to engage in what he regarded as a stimulating occupation on a part - time basis .

CARDINAL . ORG Mr ORG filed his reply on DATE . He maintained that the uncertainty concerning his admission to the Bar had made it impossible for him to find an advocate who was prepared to present him so that he could take the oath ; this obstacle could be surmounted only by the designation of an ad hoc pupil master .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , DATE and CARDINAL DATE the Legal Adviser ( auditeur ) responsible for preparing the case requested various documents from ORG , which sent them to him on DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the auditeur submitted his report , which was communicated to the applicant on DATE . He expressed the view that the ORG d’Etat had jurisdiction and that Mr ORG had an interest in having ORG decision quashed . There was no legal obligation for a law graduate to take the oath before seeking enrolment on the list of pupil advocates . The text of the decision refusing the applicant admission to that list had not cited as a reason the fact , mentioned orally on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , that FAC already had a large number of lawyers . It had referred solely to the circumstance that the applicant had completed a full career outside the Bar . Yet , in the light of the judgment of ORG CARDINAL DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , a refusal to enrol of this nature should have been grounded either on the failure to comply with the conditions laid down in LAW or on the postulant ’s unfitness or incompetence to practise as a lawyer . It followed that the reason given by ORG did not justify in law the decision of CARDINAL DATE , which should therefore be set aside .

CARDINAL . ORG On CARDINAL DATE ORG filed a final pleading , reiterating the same CARDINAL objections to the admissibility of the application ( see paragraph QUANTITY above ) . It added that the reason given fell within the scope of the wide discretion that ORG considered itself to enjoy in this area .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the President of the ORG d’Etat , PERSON , transferred the case from the ORG before which it was pending and directed that it should be heard by ORG . On DATE he postponed the public hearing until DATE as some members of the ORG d’Etat were unable to attend on DATE , the date for which it had been initially set down .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG sought leave to intervene in the proceedings . It considered Mr ORG application inadmissible . As he had not taken the oath and did not therefore satisfy one of the statutory conditions for enrolment , ORG could only have given an opinion , in respect of which an application for annulment could not lie . It argued in addition that the PERSON d’Etat lacked jurisdiction . In its view , the intention of the legislature had been that only the ordinary courts , and not the ORG d’Etat , should have jurisdiction for disputes arising from the decisions of ORG .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG gave leave for this intervention and heard the parties , after which the President reserved the decision .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the applicant complained to the President of the length of the proceedings . He allegedly received no reply .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE he laid a formal complaint with ORG for a denial of justice . On DATE he learned of the authorities’ decision not to proceed with his complaint .

CARDINAL . ORG In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE , ORG , presided over by Mr Baeteman , President of the ORG d’Etat , noted that the assembly which had heard the case up to that point had not concluded its deliberations and could no longer validly sit on account of the death of the judge - rapporteur , the appointment of CARDINAL of the judges to another post and the retirement of PERSON on DATE . It consequently decided to reopen the oral proceedings before ORG composed differently , at a hearing to be held on DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE that assembly , refusing to follow the opinion of the auditeur , Mr PERSON , ruled that the objection based on the PERSON d’Etat ’s lack of jurisdiction ratione materiae was well - founded . It took the view , inter alia :

" that having regard to the relations between the LOC and the judiciary and the concern to preserve advocates’ independence , the legislature ’s intention [ had been ] that the decisions of ORG should fall outside the scope of review by the PERSON d’Etat . Accordingly , the decisions of ORG [ could not ] be set aside by the PERSON d’Etat . The right to have his case heard by an independent and impartial national tribunal which the petitioner [ inferred ] from Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) [ of LAW ] [ did not ] mean that the PERSON d’Etat [ had ] to rule on a matter which [ fell ] outside its jurisdiction ; "
It therefore dismissed the application .
CARDINAL . ORG Each Bar has as the administrative organs for the profession of advocate ORG ( conseil de l’Ordre ) , the Chairman of ORG ( bâtonnier ) and ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG is composed of the Chairman of ORG and CARDINAL other members , according to the number of advocates on the Bar roll and the list of the pupil advocates . ORG has CARDINAL members in addition to the Chairman .
The members are directly elected by ORG , to which all advocates on the roll are convened ( LAW ) . The election is held before the end of each judicial year .

CARDINAL . ORG The ORG exercises numerous functions of an administrative , regulatory , adjudicative , advisory and disciplinary nature . For the purposes of the present case it is sufficient to mention that it is responsible for drawing up the roll of advocates and the list of pupil advocates .
CARDINAL . ORG At the material time , LAW gave the Council unfettered discretion in this respect :

" Enrolment on the roll of advocates and on the list of pupil advocates shall be determined by ORG . No appeal shall lie from its decision as it has absolute authority over the composition of the roll and the list of pupil advocates . "

An Act of DATE amended that provision by requiring that any rejection of an application for enrolment had to state reasons . In addition , under the new LAW , an appeal from such a decision lies to ORG , without prejudice to the right to file an appeal on points of law with ORG at a later stage .

Another amendment concerned the public nature of the proceedings . LAW , second paragraph , of LAW now provides : " ORG , sitting in disciplinary proceedings or as in disciplinary proceedings , shall hear the case in public , unless the advocate against whom the proceedings have been brought or the person applying for enrolment or re - enrolment requests that the proceedings be private . "
CARDINAL . ORG The enrolment of a lawyer on the list of pupil advocates or as a member of the Bar was and is governed by LAW :

" No one may bear the title of avocat or practise as an advocate unless he is a NORP national or a national of a Member ORG of ORG and possesses the degree of Doctor of Laws ; he must have taken the oath prescribed by law and be enrolled on the Bar roll or on the list of pupil advocates .
Save where the law provides otherwise , no further qualification may be added to the title avocat . "
CARDINAL . ORG As regards the taking of the oath , which is a separate formality from admission to pupillage , LAW as follows :

" The oath shall be taken at a public sitting of ORG , candidates being presented by an advocate enrolled as a member of ORG that court for not DATE , in the presence of the Chairman of ORG of the seat of ORG and at the suit of ORG " .
The candidate shall swear the following oath :

‘ I hereby swear allegiance to the King , obedience to the LAW and to the laws of the NORP people , and not to deviate from the respect due to the courts and the public authorities , or to advise or defend any cause that I do not , to the best of my knowledge and belief , hold to be just.’
The registrar shall draw up a record of the whole proceedings and endorse each diploma to certify that the formalities have been completed . "

CARDINAL . ORG To be enrolled on the list of pupil advocates a person holding a law degree , or Doctor of Laws , who has usually already taken the oath , lodges with the secretariat of ORG an application for enrolment and his diploma bearing the endorsement certifying that he has taken the oath . In principle an application for admission as a pupil advocate contains the information on the basis of which ORG can determine whether the candidate meets the required standards of integrity and decency .

CARDINAL . ORG considers whether the candidate satisfies all the requirements as to good character and thus whether he is a fit person to bear the title of avocat . It also verifies that he does not fall within any of the statutory categories of incapacity and incompatibility set out in LAW , which is worded as follows :
" The profession of advocate shall be incompatible with :
CARDINAL the posts of full - time member of the judiciary ( magistrat effectif ) , registrar and civil servant ;
CARDINAL the functions of notary ( notaire ) and bailiff ( huissier de justice ) ;
CARDINAL industrial or commercial activity ;
CARDINAL remunerated employment and activity , whether in the public or private sector , unless it does not jeopardise the independence of the advocate or compromise the dignity of the Bar .
CARDINAL . ORG has a very wide discretion in deciding whether to admit candidates to the Bar . That discretion must however be exercised within the limits laid down by the code .

Seeking to define those limits Mr Lemmens , the auditeur , in his report ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) took as authority a judgment of ORG CARDINAL DATE concerning a decision taken by ORG . Under LAW of DATE setting up ORG , that ORG was vested with powers , as regards admission to the roll , similar to those of ORG . The relevant ground of the judgment in question is worded as follows :

" ... it may be inferred from paragraph CARDINAL [ of LAW of CARDINAL DATE ] laying down the procedure for appeals against decisions refusing applications for enrolment , in the light of the purpose of that text and its legislative history , that ORG , responsible for drawing up the roll of the ORG , can found their refusal of an application for enrolment only on a defect in the qualifications on which the application is based or on the current unfitness of the candidate or on his professional incompetence . " ( Pasicrisie , I , p. CARDINAL )
